Award.AwardTitle: Discourse and prosody in non-native speakers' reference resolution

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Pronouns like 'he' and 'she' are among the most frequently used words in English. Yet neither a dictionary nor a grammar book will satisfy a learner of English as a second language who is trying to understand their full meaning and use. Pronouns often occur in contexts that contain more than one possible referent. Native speakers accumulate knowledge of patterns in the language that shift the interpretive preference one way or another. One such pattern involves the nature of the event being described: for example, a pronoun is more likely to refer to the doer of the last-mentioned action when that action is incomplete. Another pattern involves prosody, that is, what parts of a sentence receive emphasis. Native speakers deftly integrate such information to unconsciously anticipate how a conversation is going to continue, building expectations about who will be referred to next even before a name or pronoun is heard.

This project investigates how Japanese- and Korean-speaking learners of English interpret pronouns, asking specifically whether their interpretation is affected by patterns of event structure and prosody. Early evidence indicates that even when learners have advanced knowledge of English grammar, they may have a reduced ability to generate expectations during language comprehension, resulting in interpretation of pronouns different from that of native speakers. Five experiments will examine how native speakers versus learners continue written and spoken stories with pronouns, and how their eye fixations reveal, in a fraction of a second, which person in a story they think is most likely to be referred to next.

There are more second language users of English worldwide than there are native speakers as a first language. Understanding the nature of their language comprehension has the potential to improve strategies for successful communication, language teaching techniques, and our general understanding of how the human mind functions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the 21st century global economy, many interactions in political, business, educational, and personal contexts involve people communicating in a language that is not their mother tongue. Often, the language that is chosen for these situations is English. Yet most existing research on human communication, and especially research about the in-the-moment decisions we make during speaking and listening, is based on people using their native language. This project expands the research on native-English communication, and extends the insights we have gained from native-language research to assess how non-native speakers produce and comprehend English. We do so using two populations of interest for many types of communication domains, from political ones to cultural ones: native speakers of Japanese or Korean who are intermediate to advanced learners of English.

More specifically, we conducted a series of experiments with native and non-native speakers of English to test their responsiveness to subtle yet important changes in the choice of grammatical form and intonation in English, such as the contrast between –ing and –ed forms of verbs, which mark ongoing versus completed actions. We initiated the research with the hypothesis that non-native speakers may well understand and respond to such subtle changes when given enough time, but they may not use subtle cues as efficiently and automatically as native speakers to interpret language ‘on the fly’, that is, in making sense of continuous speech or text. In particular, we postulated that native speakers would readily use such cues to predict how the conversation would unfold, but learners of English would show less tendency to anticipate upcoming information, putting them at a communication disadvantage.

We ran multiple experiments that systematically varied grammatical and intonational forms and used a range of testing methods. Across experiments, non-native speakers were indeed consistently less responsive during in-the-moment language situations than native speakers to subtle changes in one of the main distinctions we investigated, even though we verified that the non-native speakers could make the correct grammatical contrast under less demanding circumstances. At the same time, however, we found that for other subtle changes, non-native speakers appeared to respond just like native speakers. For example, both native and non-native speakers reacted to certain differences in intonation by shifting their expectations about who or what will be talked about next.

 From these findings we have learned that communication involving learners of English shares many of the characteristics of communication among native English speakers. At the same time, the outcomes of this project have helped pinpoint some of the specific differences in comprehension we might see between a native speaker and a non-native learner. These results are important if we want to understand how people use language(s) to communicate in a wide variety of everyday contexts, and they are of immediate relevance to the work of applied language professionals, such as translators and interpreters, speech-language pathologists, and language instructors, as well as to the development and improvement of speech and language technology that will be applicable in the wide range of contexts where people communicate in their native language or in a language that is not their mother tongue.
